node.title: For Barbora Krejcikova, Tennis Grew on Her
node.alt: Barbora Krejcikova returning the ball to  Maria Sakkari of Greece during their semifinal match at the French Open in June.
node.description: She first played for fun, but she has gone on to win the French Open and is half of a formidable doubles team.
node.content: ["Barbora Krejcikova of the Czech Republic never dreamed of a pro tennis career.", "She did not wallpaper her bedroom with posters of great Czech players, hit balls against a wall late at night while pretending she was playing match point at Wimbledon or spend hours as a 7-year-old working out in the gym. She did once, however, after winning a local junior tournament, receive an Andre Agassi promotional poster, but does not remember what she did with it.", "\u201cI always loved tennis, always wanted to play, but only played for fun,\u201d Krejcikova said in a video conversation last month. \u201cI only realized later, when I was 16 or 17 and playing junior slams, that this was something that I would love to do. That I wanted to be in the same locker room as the superstars and play against them someday.\u201d", "Three years ago, Krejcikova was ranked outside the world\u2019s Top 200 in singles, but reached No. 1 in doubles with her countrywoman Katerina Siniakova. Now she is ranked a career-high No. 3 in singles and is the first player since another fellow Czech, Karolina Pliskova in 2016, to qualify for the WTA Finals in singles and doubles. Pliskova will also compete in the event, in Guadalajara, Mexico, which makes two of the eight singles players Czech.", "Krejcikova qualified by winning the French Open in June and reaching the quarterfinals at the United States Open and the round of 16 at Wimbledon.", "\u201cWhat happened this season, it\u2019s really hard to describe it,\u201d Krejcikova said. \u201cI mean, it\u2019s just perfect. It was this amazing season and really my big breakthrough. I\u2019m really glad that things went the way that they went.\u201d", "Krejcikova, 25, is the latest in a long line of great Czech women tennis players. Vera Sukova reached the Wimbledon final in 1962. Martina Navratilova reached two major finals while representing Czechoslovakia in 1975, then won 18 majors, including nine Wimbledons, after she defected to the United States.", "Hana Mandlikova, Jana Novotna and, more recently, Petra Kvitov\u00e1, are all major champions, and Pliskova, who reached the final at Wimbledon this year before losing to Ashleigh Barty, was ranked No. 1 in 2017. Sukova\u2019s daughter, Helena, won 14 majors in doubles.", "The Czech Republic won the Fed Cup six out of eight years, from 2011 to 2018. Krejcikova made the team, playing doubles in 2018 and \u201919. She made her singles debut in the competition, now renamed the Billie Jean King Cup, in Prague last week.", "\u201cThere is only one reason that so many Czech players have been successful, and it\u2019s because the coaches there all teach good technique,\u201d said Mandlikova, winner of four majors in the 1980s before she served as the coach of the 1998 Wimbledon winner Novotna who, in turn, became Krejcikova\u2019s mentor. \u201cSometimes that takes a little longer to develop, but it stays with you for your whole life.\u201d", "Krejcikova was not unknown as a junior. At 17 she won the 2013 European Junior Championships in singles and doubles. The same year, she and Siniakova captured junior doubles titles at the French Open, Wimbledon and the U.S. Open.", "Still playing together on the WTA Tour, the pair won the French Open and Wimbledon in 2018 and the French this year. They also won a gold medal at the Olympics in July. This is the third time they have qualified for the WTA Finals, where they were runners-up in 2018. Krejcikova is also a three-time Australian Open mixed doubles winner.", "\u201cI remember when we played the Australian Open in 2020, she was in qualifying for singles and was ranked like 120, 130 in the world,\u201d said Nikola Mektic, half of the world No. 1 doubles team. \u201cTo be Top 5 now is a major accomplishment for her. And she still keeps playing doubles and mixed, so hats off to her.\u201d", "Krejcikova has been trying to improve her singles game. From 2014 to 2019, she played the qualifying tournaments at the four majors 16 times, advancing to the main draw only once. She trained for several years at the TK Agrofert Prostejov, the same club where Kvitova trained.", "\u201cPetra is a legend,\u201d Krejcikova said. \u201cI used to watch her a lot, and I always wished that I could hit some balls with her. But then we were on the Fed Cup team together, and now I have a different perspective. It\u2019s just crazy.\u201d", "Kvitova said she believed that doubles success had made Krejcikova a better singles player. \u201cIt\u2019s the variety of her game and how she is seeing it from the doubles as well,\u201d said Kvitova, a two-time Wimbledon winner. \u201cShe has a kick serve too which not many players have. And she has drop shots, slice, topspin, serve and volley, whatever, it\u2019s all there.\u201d", "In January 2014, when she had just turned 18 years old, Krejcikova and her mother, Hana Krejcikova, knocked on the door of Novotna\u2019s house in Brno, looking for advice. Novotna agreed to work with Krejcikova.", "\u201cI would say that the connection to her was a huge guiding light for me, and I really appreciate that she gave me her time and wanted to help me and not someone else,\u201d Krejcikova said of Novotna, who died of cancer at age 49 in 2017. Because of Novotna, Krejcikova has become involved with the WTA\u2019s Aceing Cancer campaign.", "\u201cEven when everyone else was in the Top 100 and I was playing I.T.F.s [International Tennis Federation tournaments] and qualifying, she always told me: \u2018Be patient, you\u2019re going to be like me. Keep improving, and you\u2019ll get there one day.\u2019 And, out of nowhere, I\u2019m here.\u201d"]
